discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Operating Systems Affected by Shellshock
 Linux distributions (e.g., Ubuntu, Debian, CentOS, Red Hat)
 macOS (older versions, since they also use Bash by default in earlier versions)
 Unix-based systems that use Bash as the default shell

Shellshock, also known as Bashdoor,[1] is a family of security bugs[2] in the Unix Bash shell, the first of which was disclosed on 24 September 2014. Shellshock could enable an attacker to cause Bash to execute arbitrary commands and gain unauthorized access[3] to many Internet-facing services, such as web servers, that use Bash to process requests.

questions.question_text: Shellshock allowed an unauthorized user to gain access to a server. It affected many Internet-facing services, which OS did it not directly affect?

discussion.content: An anomaly-based intrusion detection system, is an intrusion detection system for detecting both network and computer intrusions and misuse by monitoring system activity and classifying it as either normal or anomalous. The classification is based on heuristics or rules, rather than patterns or signatures, and attempts to detect any type of misuse that falls out of normal system operation. This is as opposed to signature-based systems, which can only detect attacks for which a signature has previously been created.[1]

is an intrusion detection system for detecting both network and computer intrusions and misuse by monitoring system activity and classifying it as either normal or anomalous. The classification is based on heuristics or rules, rather than patterns or signatures, and attempts to detect any type of misuse that falls out of normal system operation. This is as opposed to signature-based systems, which can only detect attacks for which a signature has previously been created. I would like to reference https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anomaly-based_intrusion_detection_system as the source of this information

choices.C: Requires vendor updates for a new threat
choices.D: Cannot deal with encrypted network traffic

questions.question_text: Which of the following options represents a conceptual characteristic of an anomaly-based IDS over a signature-based IDS?

A hacker named Jack is trying to compromise a bank's computer system. He needs to know the operating system of that computer to launch further attacks.
What process would help him?

discussion.content: Correct is A: Banner grabbing: Banner grabbing or OS fingerprinting is the method used to determine the operating system running on a remote target system. Identifying the OS used on the target host allows an attacker to figure out the vulnerabilities the system posses and the exploits that might work on a system to further carry out additional attacks
banner grabbing, use telnet or nmap -O

SSDP scanning
Simple Service Discovery Protocol (SSDP) is a networking protocol used to discover the directly connected devices. This protocol uses UDP using plug and play devices in order to exchange data. It works on port 1900.

The idle scan is a TCP port scan method that consists of sending spoofed packets to a computer[1] to find out what services are available. This is accomplished by impersonating another computer called a "zombie" (that is not transmitting or receiving information) and observing the behavior of the ''zombie'' system.

questions.question_text:
Bob, a network administrator at BigUniversity, realized that some students are connecting their notebooks in the wired network to have Internet access. In the university campus, there are many Ethernet ports available for professors and authorized visitors but not for students.
He identified this when the IDS alerted for malware activities in the network.
What should Bob do to avoid this problem?

discussion.content:
ssentially, 802.1x provides a framework for port-based access control. It can work with various authentication mecha- nisms to authenticate and authorize users. The Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP, IETF RFC 2284) is a protocol commonly used in 802.1x to authenticate users.

Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) and IEEE 802.1x ...

Selected Answer: B
B. Separate students in a different VLAN

To avoid unauthorized students from connecting their notebooks to the wired network, Bob should separate them into a different Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN). VLANs are logical networks created within a physical network, and they allow the network administrator to segment the network traffic and control access based on the VLAN membership.

By placing students in a separate VLAN, Bob can restrict their access to only specific resources and services, preventing them from connecting to the same network as professors and authorized visitors. This segmentation will help improve network security and reduce the risk of malware activities and unauthorized access.

choices.B: Separate students in a different VLAN
choices.A: Disable unused ports in the switches
choices.D: Ask students to use the wireless network

discussion.content:
Bluetooth Attacks
Bluesmacking - denial of service against device
Bluejacking - sending unsolicited messages
Bluesniffing - attempt to discover Bluetooth devices
Bluebugging - remotely using a device's features
Bluesnarfing - theft of data from a device
Blueprinting - collecting device information over Bluetooth
bluesmacking =form of DDOS. Bluejacking -> unsolidated messsage to bluetooth . blue snarfing =connects and downloads files alters calendars

Bluejacking is the sending of unsolicited messages over Bluetooth to Bluetooth-enabled devices such as mobile phones, PDAs or laptop computers, sending a vCard which typically contains a message in the name field (i.e., for bluedating or bluechat) to another Bluetooth-enabled device via the OBEX protocol.

questions.question_text: Which of the following Bluetooth hacking techniques does an attacker use to send messages to users without the recipient's consent, similar to email spamming?
